page.title: 03INDUSTRY
page.content: There were many Clay-pits in the area at one time. The clay being used locally to make tiles, plant-pots and bricks for local buildings. The local streams were harnessed to provide water power for grinding corn and bone, and also for the making of silk crepe. The land produced good grass land and supported dairy herds, and allied industries such as cheese making and a tannery. Other industries which have died out are:- basket making, spinning, a paint works, coal merchants; only two small nurseries, a blacksmiths and a little farming are now in evidence. {MODERNISATION. 1862 - Railways came to the village. 1895 - Cobbled roads Macadamed. 1922 - First bus service appeared. 1923 - First telephone exchange. 1931 - Electric cables supplied.
